content.description: Climb the face on thin pockets and protrusions to the big, rectangular hole in the top of the face.
content.protection:
Standard rack. Protection is ample, if you have the experience to locate it and the wherewithal to hang out and place it. Despite the inviting grade, I would not recommend this as a beginner lead.

 There are bolted anchors with rap rings in the sill of the "window". They can be safely reached from the top of the formation for top roping.
content.location: In the middle of the left-most section of the Sun Wall, to the left of Misty.

content.description:
One of Sand Rock's classic trad lines, White Gold is a burly lead with nice exposure.  If you're not a solid 5.10 leader and/or good at hand-jamming, you're probably not ready for this one. 

  Starting in a sort of shallow chimney, follow the pebbly rock up to a left-facing corner.  Jam the crack up to a roof, then move right onto the face and on to the top.
content.protection: Standard trad rack -- small to medium gear.  Bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: Starts in a sandy clearing, just right of the cave that leads to the Whipping Post, and around the corner left of Knob Wall.  Rap from the anchors.

content.description: Start behind low roof on sharp jugs. Pull the roof and crimp your way through 2 or 3 bolts of pebbly rock, to some better holds. Crux is below the roof, where the holds get less painful, but much thinner. Figure out your sequence, then pull the final roof on surprisingly good holds.
content.protection: Stick Clip may be wise. Quickdraws & chain anchor
content.location: Directly to the right of Misty on the next section of Sun Wall. Just left of Bocephus.

content.description:
An unusual route in that it doesn't follow a plumb line, Wall of Horns is a thought-provoking climb through juggy but overhanging conglomerate.  But first, you've got to get through that long and spicy traverse. 

  Starting on the left side of a wide crack, climb about 10-15' to a point where there's enough positive hands and feet to begin moving left across the face.  Continue the delicate traverse another 20' or so left and up to gain the namesake horns that will lead you to the anchors at the top.
content.protection: Marginal.  This would be an R/X-rated lead and is best done as a toprope.  Wearing a helmet is recommended, as a fall during the traverse will result in a long pendulum.  Bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: In the Whipping Post area; starts on the wall across from Dreamscape left of a prominent crack.

content.description: Slabby awkward start, either from the crack or direct I'm not sure. Move up through two underclinger bulges and on whatever edges you can find. Cool under clings but the rest isn't too remarkable.
content.location: Last bolted line of far right of the sand trap area, right of Misty. Right of a 5.9 crack and next to another shorter crack. Tree near the first bolt.

content.description: Bouldery crux of the ground leads to gear and better holds.  Mini crux near the lone bolt.  Very featured and textured climbing.  You won't need much chalk.
content.location: Just down and right of Muffins Are Burning.  Right of Unknown 1.

content.description: This newer(?) line climbs very textured rock to the right and up an arête on the left side of the wall past 1 bolt to anchors.
content.location: Located to the right of Muffins are Burning.  On the arête of the next wall.

content.description: A thin bouldery start to first bolt leads to positive holds. Located just left of Lichen This. Johnny Arms gives us another reason to visit this corridor.
content.location: From the Whipping Post area scramble up the boulders to the right of Wall Of Horns to a corridor on the back side or scramble down from the campsites.

content.description:
A somewhat overlooked route with the super popular Misty just to the right, Super Grover is one of my favorite lines at Sand Rock.  Climb moderate moves up and right along a pebbly crack for the first few bolts and then set up for the crux move off an awkward left hold, reaching for a "bread loaf" hold high up.  After a cool cross-through move, fight the pump up the steep wall to the chains. 

  The crux on this route is probably harder than the DCA's 11b/c rating would lead you to believe, especially if you're on the wee side.  I do it statically, but I've heard others throw to the loaf.
content.location: First bolted route to the left of Misty.  This route gets toasty warm as the sun hits it early.

content.description: Face climb to series of stepped roofs. Beware the rope drag.
content.location: Elevated belay area just before the Sandburger crack area.

content.description: The same route as Nothingness, except stem for the first 20 ft/3 bolts. Hardest move is transitioning from stemming to the wall, then climb run-out jugs to the top.
content.location: Duck through the corridor in between Misty and Knob Wall to get to the Whipping Post, same bolts as Nothingness.

content.description:
A really fun sport route, featuring a tenuous start, thin slab/face climbing and a roof pull at the finish. 

  Starting next to a looming boulder, balance your way up onto the slab.  Continue up to a shallow roof (protected by a bolt); pull the roof and continue to the anchors.
content.location: Follow the Sun Wall trail past the Whipping Post area a good ways until you reach a section where large blocks stand between you and the main wall.  Crawl between the boulders to the start of Sneakers and Eclipse (a gear route to the left of Sneakers).

content.description: Climb a ramp up, right and then left to a prominent chimney.  Step out of chimney at the top to short face and crack climbing.
content.protection: Standard Sandrock rack, bring runners, WEAR HELMET (you will hit your head!)  Trad anchor at top.  Walk of left and scramble back down.
content.location: Located in an "alley" behind Misty and Windows

content.description: Traverse left on crimps, cruise the slab and pull the roof to anchors
content.location: in the whipping post, start 5ft left of Dreamscape.

content.description: An excellent and often overlooked route!  Start in a pebbly crack to the first bolt, then sequence your way up a steep face on excellent rock. Cruxes involve some side pulls and long reaches, though don't be shy - this is not a height dependent route. Do it!
content.location: Walking from misty to knob wall, this is located alongside 3/4 other routes, on a tall orange face behind some large boulders. It is the second route from the left

content.description: Stout 5.11 climbing to the last bolt leads to a very hard boulder problem before anchors. There is some dirty lichen at the top, but all of the handholds are clean.
content.location: Left of Rave

content.description: Starting from large boulder, climb up to the left of small overhang then follow bolts up trending right to slab runout up to anchors below small roof.
content.protection: 5 bolts, anchors - runout on slab after 5th bolt to anchors
content.location: First route on far left end of Sun Wall. Starting from large boulder to the left of boulder start for Land of Silk and Money.

content.description: Climb the face to the large diagonal shelf. Make your way over the shelf after the 3rd bolt. Continue up the slab and pull the second roof to the anchors
content.location: Between sandburger and sandburger platter, start somewhat right of the cave to the whipping post.

content.description: Boulder the opening section on small (painful) flakes and crimpers until a good rest.  Continue working better flakes and edges to another rest before the top section.
content.location: Next to Midget Digits...they share the same anchor

content.description: Climb up a boulder to a large, right-facing, conglomerated flake from hell. Head to the top of the flake, then up the overhanging, right-leaning finger crack. Finish up the overhanging face to anchors at the top.
content.protection: fists to fingers, bolts and rings at the top
content.location: Left side of the left-most section of the Sun Wall. On the left side of the "amphitheater" that Misty is in.

content.description:
Another "mystery" climb at Sand Rock. I have no idea who initially put it up, or when. So I just made up a name for it. If anyone knows legit first ascent info, please fill in the blanks. 

  Start on the face just right of the arete. A crimpy start leads to larger flakes and chicken heads. Continue up past the bolt to a chain/ring anchor at the top.
content.protection: light rack, one bolt, bolted anchors at top
content.location: On the way uphill to Muffins are Burning from the main trail, you pass by an arete on your right. This climb goes up the right side of the arete, past a bolt about halfway up.

content.description:
Climb up sandy rock past some large, right-facing flakes and them some conglomerate to get to the main event -- the overhanging hand crack through the roof. Jam your way to glory!

 Once you're through the business, you can continue straight up to the top and build a gear anchor in some horizontals. To get down, either rap from one of the other routes' anchors or do the walkoff down the far end of the formation.
content.protection:
Doubles of hand sizes. A #4 Camalot is nice to have for the crack below the roof, but isn't required. 

  No anchors at the top. Build a gear anchor and walk off.
content.location: In the corridor behind the first part of the Sun Wall. From the popular sport climb Misty, walk around climber's right and into the corridor. As you scramble up the corridor, there will be an obvious crack system on the left that goes through a roof about 40 feet up.

content.description: Crux is between the ground and the 5th bolts, sustained 12b/c climbing to jugs, runout to the top, don't fall.
content.location: On the wall across the corridor from Dreamscape.

content.description: Stick clip the first bolt. Pull a bouldery bulge right off the ground(crux). This crux is extremely tricky. Get set up on the slab and put in some pitiful gear. One more short crux after the next bolt and finish on White Gold
content.location: Just around the corner to the right of White Gold

content.description: Fight your way up to a decent crimp below the first bolt and clip it.  Now reach for decent rounded holds and incut edges.  Work your way up on easier ground to the cold shuts.
content.location: If you are standing in front of Sneakers walk directly left through the corridor and the route is up and to the right.

content.description:
An exciting roofy start leads to mellower climbing on positive holds. 

  Starting under a roof below a slanting crack, make a tough, reachy move or two past the roof and into the crack.  Cruise up to another less strenuous overhang; pull through this and continue up the face to the top. 

About the names:  This is one of three undocumented climbs on the Burly Girls pinnacle that I found myself referring to as the Three Stooges.  These have been climbed for many years, but I've not been able to find anyone who knows the real names for FAs.  I don't like posting "unnamed" routes, so until I learn otherwise, they are Larry, Moe and Curly.
content.protection: Small to medium gear, and slings for the chickenheads.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts about 5' right of Larry below a slanting crack.  Rap from the anchors.

climbs.name: Misty
climbs.fa: Penny Jordan, Darrell Jordan, Brett Blackwelder - 1991

content.description: If Comfortably Numb is the must-do trad line, Misty is the sport route not to be missed at Sand Rock.  From crimpers to thin moves on a bulge to positive holds on steep overhang, Misty has it all.  An outstanding and memorable lead.
content.protection: Seven bolts, bolted anchors. Anchors are equipped with hooks for lowering.
content.location: Starts near the right end of the Sun Wall buttress, about 20' right of First Black in Space.

content.description: Tiny, crimpy holds (hence the name) give way to better holds up high, where you step up below a roof before the final climbing on great flakes.
content.protection: 6 bolts, anchors and a clip stick
content.location: Keep walking past Misty and Knob Wall as the trail comes back close to the wall, look for an opportunity to step up between to large boulders.  M.D. is the left bolted line.

content.description: Climb up the easy slab to belay under the bolted crack. The crack is bolted, remember this is Sand rock, this is far from the most disgusting thing you'll see here. Difficult clip over the bulge, rest, launch into thin holds followed by a dyno, to big jug. Trend left up more difficult face moves to anchor.
content.location: Starts in a recessed alcove above the trail in the Sand Trap section of Sun Wall, about 20' right of Pit Stop.

content.description: Located in the corridor behind Misty, about 15 right of the arete.  Also about 10 right of Hacienda, the first sport route behind Misty.  Use cheater stones to reach the first right-hand crimp, climb up slab (11d) to a huge conglomerated crack and to a huge jug out right, clip the last bolt with a hidden undercling and reach for a high right crimp, dyno to a large sloping jug with the left hand (12b) and you're done. May feel like 12c if you are tall.
content.location: Not to be confused with Hacienda, the first route on the left wall of the corridor.

content.description: Short fun route that's a great warm-up or a great first lead. Crux is towards the top between the third and fourth bolt.
content.location: Scramble up the boulders behind Dreamscape or scramble down from the campsites. In the area known as "The Whipping Post."

content.description:
Don't let the fun, juggy climbing down low lull you into complacency -- there's some tricky, hard-to-protect moves toward the top. 

  Starting just right of a prominent boulder, pull through an overhang onto nice conglomerated knobs.  If the overhang seems too hard, you can bypass it by stemming between the boulder and the wall and then transition onto the face.  Continue up the face right of the blunt arete and finesse your way through slopers to reach the anchors. 

About the names:  This is one of three undocumented climbs on the Burly Girls pinnacle that I found myself referring to as the Three Stooges.  These have been climbed for many years, but I've not been able to find anyone who knows the real names for FAs.  I don't like posting "unnamed" routes, so until I learn otherwise, they are Larry, Moe and Curly.
content.protection: Small to medium gear, with plentiful opportunities to sling horns.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts just right of the corridor that leads to Pile Driver.  Rap from the anchors.

content.description: A fun route that sports interesting opening moves.  Squeeze your way up the bulging arete/corner feature to arrive at the headwall.  Tiptoe up thin flakes and sidepulls to the chains.
content.location: At the far left end of Sun Wall.  Starts off the boulder just right of Prom Queen.

content.description:
Knob Wall is a great route to take neophyte climbers.  Like the name says, it's easy climbing on plentiful jugs, and it's a nice long route with a great view of the valley below.  Knob Wall is also a good choice for new trad leaders, who can sew it up with gear and learn how to sling horns as well. 

  Starting just left of a large boulder, climb the face to a small ledge (little to no pro in the first 15').  Follow the jugs and horns up to anchors at the top.
content.protection: Small to medium gear, plus slings for the horns.  Bolted anchors (or shuts) at the top.
content.location: Starts just around the corner from White Gold, not far down the trail from Misty.

content.description: Really easy climbing to the first bolt about 15" up.  Crux is a killer slope/crimp move between the 2nd and 3rd bolt. The route is way under its grade everywhere but that crux. It's worth doing just to make that one move.
content.location: Route is in the crevice closest to the camps behind Sneakers. Easy access by taking the steep trail and then turning left. The route is the only sport route near the end of the corridor.

content.description:
They say everything's been climbed here at Sand Rock, so even though it's not in the guidebook, there's no doubt that this route has been done in the distant past by someone like Rich Gottlieb who just never bothered to tell anyone.  Since it's not documented, I'm giving it a name so other trad leaders may decide to sample its pleasures. 

  Starting in a prominent crack, follow the crack to where it splits a roof about 30' up.  Pull through the roof to a nice ledge, then continue on easier ground to the top.
content.protection: A rack of mostly medium gear (cams and passive gear); nuts work well.  Build a gear anchor at the top.
content.location: Starts in the crack between Wall of Horns and Glasstic.  To descend, top out and walk left to the anchors for Wall of Horns.
Around the back side of Misty in the corridor, between Misty and Lip Service. First bolted route on the left in the corridor.

content.description: There are probably a few slight variations to this climb but essentially...start from the boulder and climb the steep face with flakes up to a horizontal crack.  Then either go right and hit a finger crack and traverse back left and pull the roof/notch...or go straight up through more flake then pull the roof.  The first option provides more options for gear and a spicy traverse.
content.protection: Trad gear.  No anchor at the top, but there is a big horn and horizontals at the top.
content.location: Located in the "Whipping Post" area, behind Knob Wall, et al, next to Wall of Horns.

content.description: Start to the right of the first draw on small painful crimps and work left into a nice rest from the 2nd bolt to the third.  Muscle up some go-go juice to work up under the mini roof.  Work right and connect with Changing Landscapes to the top.  **Nuts on the bolts need to be tightened.  I hand-tightened best I could.**
content.location: It is the line to the right of Rave, just to the left of Changing Landscapes and 2 over from Liquid Spirits.

content.description:
Starts about 10 feet left of the bolted climb Misty, beneath an obvious right-facing flake system. Climb up to and over the flake system, then step left and up to bolts inside a large, rectangular opening near the top of the cliff. 

  The Dixie Cragger's has this one listed as 5.9+, but we didn't find anything that felt harder than 5.8. The guidebook mentions the option of taking it all the way to the top, so maybe there's some 5.9 up there?
content.protection: single rack, bolted anchors in the "window" cave
content.location: On the first section of Sun Wall you come to, just to the left of the ever-popular sport climb Misty.

content.description: Climb Dreamscape to the last bolt, then tweak over a technical V5ish boulder problem directly up or slightly right. Finish with a desperate final move to the jugs over anchors, which are the same anchors as for Dreamscape.
content.protection: 8 bolts to anchor. Last bolt is awkwardly shared with Dreamscape.
content.location: Behind Knob Wall.

content.description: This route starts from the top of a boulder on the back of the wall that contains White Gold.  The moves off the ground are thin and require good foot work.  After several bolts there is a rest followed by steep juggy climbing.  Go straight up for 12d or move out left to easier ground.  I would have to say the best route of its grade at SR.

Climb an interesting finger crack to the first bolt, then use every bit of wingspan and shoe rubber you can summon to transition to the arete. Fight the barn door for a couple of bolts and top out onto a ledge.
content.location: Around the corner left of dreamscape. Obvious crack and arete.

content.description: Start on the pillar, step across, and follow sloping horizontals past the bolts to the anchors.
content.location: Starts just right of Dreamscape. Located in the Cavern within the Sun Wall.

content.description:
Though not as juggy as its neighbors, Curly is a fun romp through a conglomerated face, with a nice ledge that will give beginners a good breather.  NOTE:  pro is scanty in the first 30' or so, so unless you're prepared to run it out on lead, toproping might be a better choice. 

  Starting just right of a pine tree next to the wall, climb through knobs and the occasional horn to a spacious ledge.  Continue up the face to the top. 

About the names:  This is one of three undocumented climbs on the Burly Girls pinnacle that I found myself referring to as the Three Stooges.  These have been climbed for many years, but I've not been able to find anyone who knows the real names for FAs.  I don't like posting "unnamed" routes, so until I learn otherwise, they are Larry, Moe and Curly.
content.protection: Mostly small gear; slung horns will make you breathe a little easier.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts about 15' right of Moe, 20' left of Burly Girls.  Rap from the anchors.

content.description: Climb the raw, conglomerated handcrack and flake.   Gain a large ledge and rest.   Face climb to the offwidth and continue to the top.
content.protection: A well-sorted single rack from small to 4".
content.location: On the opposite wall from 'Overhanging Jam Crack'.

content.description: The start is easy to the first bolt and crux to bolt 2.  I've been told some rock broke making this route a little more stiff than the original.  Clip bolt 2 high for protection and work the 2nd crux.  Once you land the flakes, it is easy going to the anchor.
content.location: 10 feet to the right of Geraldine and left of Liquid Spirit.

content.description: Crack climbing leads to easy face moves on this nice moderate.  Starting in a left-facing corner, follow the crack to its end, then move left and up on easy (but sparsely protected) ground to the top of the small pinnacle.
content.protection: The crack has good pro; a #4 or 5 camalot or similar will protect the start.  Smaller stuff is needed toward the top.  New ring anchors.
content.location: Past the boulder-strewn section of the Sun Wall trail, look for an oak tree.  Burly Girls starts on the left side of the tree.

content.description: Sharp holds lead to an interesting roof move.  Multiple cruxes keep the route exciting.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a sad excuse for an anchor
content.location: On the Sun Wall just past Misty.

content.description: Follows the crack and flake system immediately left of Super Grover to a defined boulder problem crux followed by large knobs and slots. While the wall may look blank where the crack ends, surprisingly it's all there!!
content.protection: Bolted anchor above the wall, a few feet back

content.description: Climb parallel cracks through bulge and then move left on horns avoiding upper overhang. Climbing direct through notch in roof instead raises grade to 11d.
content.location: Between Misty and Hacienda, overhangs the west side of the Sandtrap and faces east.

content.description: Start by climbing the same boulder as for Popular Science, but start a bit to the right and head for the finger crack to the right of Popular Science. Reach up and clip the first bolt, then a funky move gets you off the boulder and into the joys of climbing a conglomerated finger crack. Things soon turn to face climbing, and before you know it you're at the anchors!
content.protection: 4 bolts, anchors -- The 5.6 "runout" to the anchors that is mentioned in the guidebook really isn't that bad. When you get there, you'll probably be perfectly comfortable not placing any additional protection.
content.location: Left end of the Sun Wall. Starts off the same boulder as Popular Science (Golden Flake), but a little to the right.

content.description: Crux is extra crimpy off the ground on a unique overhanging prow.  Like a V6/7 boulder problem to a jug to an 11c/d short face.  Was an open project for 12 years.
content.protection: 3 bolts, tape the first b/c it rubs the rock
content.location: 100 feet? left of Faith in a small cave, starts off of a boulder on an overhanging prow.

content.description: Pretty easy start leads to a tricky slabby finish to anchors after clipping the last bolt. Feel free to tell me the name of the route/who did the FA and I'll add it; don't think this route is in any guidebook either.
content.protection: 3 bolts and two rap rings, can scramble to the top (by following the wall to the right of the climb) to set a top rope
content.location: Bolted line directly to the right of Lichen This

content.description:
With its southern exposure, the aptly-named Sun Wall is a great place to climb in the winter (and to be avoided in the hot summer months).  This cliffline runs parallel to the road into Sand Rock, and in many places you'll see roadside campsites across the way after topping out.  The wall is actually a series of free-standing towers detached from the main wall; in many places, the gap is narrow enough to jump across and hike back down to the trail. 

  The Sun Wall is best known for great sport routes like Misty, but there's also a number of fine trad lines here as well.  It's also a good place to get away from the crowds at the Pinnacle and Holiday Block.
